awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  IMPROVING BEHAVIORAL ASSESSMENT OF CHILDREN DIAGNOSED WITH AUTISM SPECTRUM DISORDER THROUGH ENHANCED DATA ACQUISITION
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase I project intends to improve the outcomes of children diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) by providing critical data from non-clinical settings that are currently unavailable to autism treatment providers. The project also focuses on accelerating the analysis of that data. It is estimated that the costs associated with ASD will be more than $2 million over a patient's life. However, studies have shown that the costs of lifetime care for a child diagnosed with ASD can be reduced by 2/3 with early intervention. Designing an appropriate treatment program, and then monitoring its efficacy, requires the collection of a range of data to avoid dependence on inference and anecdotes. Treatment providers often collect detailed data while working with an individual diagnosed with ASD, but they count on parents and caregivers to provide them with data regarding the child's progress outside the clinical setting. The data submitted are usually incomplete and inadequate (if submitted at all). This SBIR Phase I project will result in a prototype that will rapidly provide autism treatment providers with critical data and analysis, reducing the amount of time it takes to design an optimal treatment program, and thereby reducing the long-term costs associated with a diagnosis of ASD.


This Phase I project will result in a prototype that will make the process of logging data almost frictionless for parents. That narrative data will be combined with video data, biometric data, and additional data collected passively from external sources. All the data will be merged, and then analyzed via machine learning to locate patterns and provide a complete picture to the child's behavior analyst. Developing a camera that will be unobtrusive enough for a child with ASD to tolerate will present a challenge, as will developing the associated software to tag items within the camera's view and save only relevant clips (such as the times immediately before, during and after a meltdown). It will also be challenging to develop a wearable device that a child with ASD will tolerate, along with the associated sensors and software to track metrics associated with arousal and stress. The most significant technical challenge, however, will be to develop the software that combines the multiple data streams and outputs a standardized ABC report (Antecedent, Behavior, Consequence) that would be judged as high quality by a Board Certified Behavior Analyst.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
There are about 1.4 million children in the US who have been diagnosed with autism, and this year we?ll spend about $50 billion dollars on services for them. The standard of care for these kids is called Applied Behavioral Analysis, or ABA. ABA relies heavily on data, but we?re currently missing about 60% of the data we need to do it well. A typical autistic child spends most of his waking hours at home, but almost no data is collected by parents and caregivers. This creates a huge blind spot for behavior analysts.

Supported by an SBIR grant from the NSF, SpinRise Technologies has completed research to help solve this problem. The company spent 18 months investigating an ambitions solution: a system that combines narrative, biometric and video data to give ABA practitioners a complete picture and allow them to optimize a therapy program for an autistic child. The objective of this research was to prove that there was a viable way to collect, aggregate, and analyze critical behavioral data about an autistic child without requiring a trained professional on-site, and without requiring significant effort from parents and caregivers. At a high level, the company hopes that this research not only accelerates the development of optimal treatment programs for autistic children, but also makes effective treatment more widely available.

The company?s hypothesis was that components existed that could be combined to collect the desired data for ABA practitioners in a manner that would still be highly effective and attractive in the marketplace. The goal was to demonstrate a working prototype of the system outlined in the attached diagram. Components were therefore evaluated in these four areas: biometric, video, narrative and external data collection.

Devices to collect biometric data were evaluated based on the following criteria:

  1. Correlation to Stress: the data that the device collected had to be backed by research validating that it was correlated to an individual?s stress level.
  2. Durability
  3. Tolerability
  4. Cost Effectiveness: since the goal is to ultimately release a product to the mass market, specialized, expensive research devices were excluded.

After testing several devices, the team initially moved forward with the Empatica E4 wristband. However, while the data collected were robust and were shown to correlate with an individual?s stress levels, the interface proved to be too fragile for use on a typical child with ASD.

The team then moved forward with a Spire Health Tag. Spire Health Tags are employed by affixing them inside the waistband of a child?s underwear. They are almost completely unobtrusive, the battery lasts for more than a year, and they can go through the wash. Although the Spire Health Tag did not collect the same range of data as the Empatica E4, its proprietary respiratory sensor is backed by research linking its data to stress levels. This method of biometric data collection proved to be the most effective and was the one ultimately utilized by the SpinRise Team.

The collection of video data provided several challenges, especially since most consumer-grade connected cameras are highly closed systems due to privacy concerns. The team therefore moved forward with building their own custom camera utilizing Raspberry Pi. While the camera was highly customizable, durable, and cost effective, it quickly became apparent that it wouldn?t be a viable option for a mass market product. Potential investors were extremely wary of backing a company producing custom hardware, and potential consumers were wary of utilizing a camera that was not from a brand they recognized. Therefore, the team moved to develop a custom interface between the SpinRise platform and almost any camera that could upload video to the cloud. The team ultimately settled on this abstraction layer as the best solution.

The team was determined to ensure that the input of narrative data was completely painless and seamless for parents and caregivers. One of the team?s key insights was that most parents and caregivers send text messages to other loved ones before, during, and after a child?s meltdown. Therefore, they built a system that allowed input via text message, which meant that parents would not have to change their behavior to record narrative data onto the SpinRise platform.

The team at SpinRise Technologies is extremely fortunate to have had the opportunity to study a new method of helping autistic children and their families through the backing of the NSF?s SBIR program. The company was able to complete a working prototype of its application and demonstrate its ability to collect data that are extremely valuable to families with autistic children and the professionals working to help them.


Last Modified: 03/25/2021
Modified by: Gary Higginson

Image
  • High level overview of the data collection system developed by SpinRise Technologies LLC.
    SpinRise Technologies LLC
